pr_title: Rich text viewer | Implementation of markdown parser
text:
The challenge is that the Chromatic snapshots are identical for cases that should look different, so the tests aren't actually verifying that the sizing behavior is correct. For example [in the Chrome screenshots](https://www.chromatic.com/test?appId=60e89457a987cf003efc0a5b&id=64b1306799bade1409c030c5) the scrollbar isn't visible so the only indication of the height and width is where the text clips, which is an imperfect indication of its size.

I can see a few options to test this behavior:
1. apply test-only styling to the rich-text-viewer to render its size. e.g. `outline: 1px dashed red`
2. if the final visual design is ready and includes a border, adopt that styling to achieve the same effect
3. change these to be unit tests which call `getComputedStyle()` on the viewer. The downside of this is that it won't test render behaviors at different sizes like word wrapping

I'm fine with any of them but 1 is probably the simplest option to move this PR forward.

text:
> There is a [diff on the "Simple" radio-button-group story](https://www.chromatic.com/test?appId=6266d45509d7eb004aa254fb&id=659f4b5fe6fddfcc8aef0d02) because you can't set a string knob's value to undefined. I [set it to "" instead](https://github.com/Esri/calcite-design-system/blob/benelan/radio-validation-message/packages/calcite-components/src/components/radio-button-group/radio-button-group.stories.ts), but that makes the prop truthy, which ends up matching [these CSS selectors](https://github.com/Esri/calcite-design-system/blob/8be513b40a54b882ae8889e5d6a42ab98a55e378/packages/calcite-components/src/components/radio-button-group/radio-button-group.scss#L31-L37). Is there a better way to do this or is it okay as is?

Unfortunately, there doesn't seem to be a clean way to set `undefined` on knobs. Is this the only story that is showing different styling due to the presence of `validation-message`? If so, I think we could do one of the following:

1. keep as is
2. create a separate story to set validation props
3. remove validation props from simple story

It'd be good to add a note in the story regardless of the option.

> I wanted to do something like the following snippet, but --calcite-input-message-spacing-value doesn't seem to have any effect, even when setting it to 500px for testing. Unless I'm doing something wrong?

It looks like the label CSS prop [doesn't have a default value and label's bottom margin will use a fall back in this case](https://github.com/Esri/calcite-design-system/blob/main/packages/calcite-components/src/components/label/label.scss#L34).

text:
Sorry, this should actually be comparing the event code object's parent to the current "object descriptor". Otherwise we're comparing a function object to a class object, and this will always fail. See the regression here:
https://www.chromatic.com/test?appId=5fe18baf66f2280021e634d0&id=6000ae7633d715002116bc43

This also seems to work in my testing:
```
e.codeObject.parent === this.objectDescriptor
```

Which is great, because it's a lot more concise. For some reason I was thinking the comparison wouldn't work due to one of the objects being copied somewhere, but that doesn't seem to be the case.

Could you also add a unit test for this? It'd be great to know we're avoiding that regression again in the future.

Our pattern of passing args via a `decorator` function isn't working: https://github.com/storybookjs/storybook/blob/1e39b02c1001d2e527d74558f6298267e3d6ec38/code/lib/store/template/stories/argTypes.stories.ts#L8-L12 I don't know angular well enough to say for sure, but I'm reasonably sure this isn't resulting in `args.object` being set on the rendered story. 2. Similarly, in this story, the button renders as "Button" not "Clicked X times" https://github.com/storybookjs/storybook/blob/1e39b02c1001d2e527d74558f6298267e3d6ec38/code/lib/store/template/stories/hooks.stories.ts#L15-L23 https://www.chromatic.com/test?appId=6322ce6af69825592bbb28fc&id=633e5fc2f266eeeadf703d4f: 3. I copied what the button story does but it doesn't seem to be working. Any ideas?

Now that the story has been created, you can see that the Nimble PR pipeline includes some new Chromatic tests which render that story and compare it to a baseline. This is how we test that our styles are behaving as expected. You can see the build for this PR here (visible on the PR's Conversation tab in Status section near the bottom): https://www.chromatic.com/test?appId=60e89457a987cf003efc0a5b&id=638096c47134646d9494ac1a

The challenge is that Chromatic takes a snapshot of the component appearance as soon as it thinks the page has loaded. If there is still rendering happening after the page has loaded, the snapshot may be non-deterministic. You can see this in the link above: the snapshot created for Chrome shows "Loading..." while the snapshot in Firefox shows basic data. This is just caused by timing differences and it will cause problems for test reliability.

For this PR, I'd propose that we remove the artificial delay and the `renderReady` flag, just to simplify things.

Longer term, one option would be to implement a [play() function](https://storybook.js.org/docs/react/writing-stories/play-function) which would ensure the component is in the correct state before taking the snapshot.

Alternatively, we could make `renderReady` be part of the public API and write a dedicated test with it set to `false` and a dedicated test with it set to `true`.

This class should be conditionally be set if there is slotted content or not. See https://www.chromatic.com/test?appId=5ea7d9e48c451f00223b52ff&id=6380cec29ac24f83b5e6afcb . Now there is an invisible space on the right side, if there is no label.

Thanks so much for continuing to work on this! It's super exciting to see it coming along.

> I wonder if we should selectively enable it or selectively disable it.

I think so too. In the [above example](https://www.chromatic.com/test?appId=629132c6e23893003a9e89c5&id=65351c2484824a8adc993e12) I think it looks particularly rough with the small text, but I think on larger text it's probably fine. I'm totally up for whatever makes sense, though. I think most links are a different color, so I think that's a valid solution too.

> Global error state needs to not look so basic

Most people shouldn't ever see it, so I'm not terribly concerned. The most likely case for somebody to see it is when they're working on Owncast development, and they shut down the backend.
